How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication o

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.

Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous

Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could sh

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got les

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking.

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I wa

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I reall

I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty sm

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was p

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on t

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you a

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody

Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass th

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come acro

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a fi

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.

I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she respond

Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the race

We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny t

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny thing is, if you think about it...we never would have ev

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny thing is, if you think about it...we never would have even met if it weren'

I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny thing is, if you think about it...we never would have even met if it weren't for technology

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny thing is, if you think about it...we never would have even met if it weren't for technology. So I say thank you

How Do You Think Technology Affects Dating?

Have you had any experience with dating? Have you ever used dating apps? If so, what has it been like for you? If not, why not?

How do you think technology — like apps, Netflix, social media and texting — affects dating and relationships? In your opinion, does it improve or worsen romantic interactions? How so?

---

In my opinion, technology has greatly improved dating. I've found that dating apps in particular increase the odds of finding a relationship, at least for me. Just having the ability to use Tinder or Bumble takes away the nerves from introducing yourself to someone in person. Breaking that ice is what I find the most difficult. Being able to talk to someone via a messaging app gives me a good indication on whether or not we are compatible.

Obviously there is still stress when it comes to dating even with the advancement of technology. Ultimately, no matter how well you know someone via the internet or via messaging apps, that first meeting is person is very nerve wracking. 
I think technology does a really good job in helping alleviate anxiety, but it never fully prepares you for a first impression.
 I may be extremely comfortable speaking to someone via text or messenger but may be too nervous in person and those nerves could show.

Personally, I have had a ton of experience as I am now 30 years old. I felt that over time I got less nervous. It's kind of like anything. The more you do something the more confident you get. I remember my first date I actually spoke to a girl online a ton. Meeting her I was so nervous because I really liked her and felt she liked me as well. We finally met and things went pretty smoothly, much better than I was expecting considering how nervous I was. I look back at that first date and laugh because I was putting so much pressure on myself for no reason.

Technology lets us break the ice and then ultimately when you're on the date you just have to be yourself. The other person is probably just as nervous as you are. After all, nobody wants to embarrass themselves or come across negatively on a first date. Of course there are first dates that just don't go well. That's a part of life. 

But overall, technology has definitely helped me in my dating experiences. My current girlfriend I met on Tinder. I swiped right, she responded back to me and we were off to the races. And the funny thing is, if you think about it...we never would have even met if it weren't for technology. So I say thank you technolog
